Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2007 06:29AM aussiejan wrote: This is a question for which I, too, would like an answer. I had a lumpectomy 20mm IDC grade 2, associated DCIS high and intermediate grade - 1/16 nodes positive, dose dense AC and Taxol x 4 of each, 8 weeks rads and now on Arimidex. Finished rads in early May.

How Do You Handle All of the Phone Calls? figsgirls joanne_elizabeth

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2010 07:59PM aussiejan wrote: Hi Cat123  I had dose dense Adriamycin and Cyclophosphamide x 4 followed by 4 rounds of Taxol, also dose dense. This is considered to be the gold standard and, although it does not give you a 'good' week, it does get chemo over and done in a shorter time! I am four years out from treatment now so there is light. I really sympathise with your thoughts about losing your hair.  I had mine cut very short so that I felt as though I had some control.  As it was summer when I was having treatment I didn't worry about hats or scarves.  I was okay with it and my family were okay with it and we figured no-one else mattered. Best wishes to you as you embark on this next stage.  DD ACT is very doable.
Posts.Title: ACT Dose Dense Cat123 Cat123

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2010 07:59PM aussiejan wrote: Hi Limegreen, Up to a few weeks ago I would have said no lingering consequences of any note other than the balls of my feet feeling 'different'. Of late, however, I have been diagnosed with an enlarged left lobe thyroid with nodes.  While all thyroid blood levels are in the normal range, albeit high, the only abnormal results are thyroid antibodies which are way out of whack. The investigations for this were because of shortness of breath, cough and a sometimes raspy voice.  I am being referred to an endocrinologist for this. My recent Onc review last week, and my onc is concerned about the shortness of breath and is sending me for a cardiac echo.  He has explained that it may be due to toxicity from dose dense AC + T, 4 rounds of each.  He said that while this does not happen often as a late onset (three years out from end of chemo) it does happen and may manifest itself as cardiomyopathy or congestive cardiac failure.  Whoopee.  I am not worrying at this point, time enough when I know what I am dealing with.  He did say that it was unlikely the thyroid was related to the chemo or rads but his offsider said not to ignore the thyroid issue as it, too, could cause cardiac failure.  I think it is time to stop going to the doctors!  I was a very healthy woman before breast cancer.  LOL
Posts.Title: in the years after TC treatment limegreen hrf

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2010 01:15AM aussiejan wrote: Otter, I have done a great deal of research in the last few days.  Adriamycin and Cyclophosphamide are definitely known to cause cardiac issues.  I am hoping that it is more related to the thyroid than the chemo but time and tests will tell.
